display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Games Lab → GL-03. Cluster 3 → GL-03-C02

results.title: Image contagion
results.brief_description: Smartphones democratised the moving image. With the power to record at our fingertips, we’re able to share information, bear witness and incite action. By capturing events from multiple perspectives, we have the power to challenge official narratives, speak truth to power and expose tyranny.

constellations_primary.name: Confronting injustice on-screen
constellations_primary.description: The Black Lives Matter movement and the treatment of African Americans at the hands of authorities is explored in this Constellation that connects hip-hop, the Civil Rights Movement and representation in Hollywood.

results.description: Smartphones democratised the moving image. With the power to record at our fingertips, we’re able to share information, bear witness and incite action. Our relationship to the moving image has shifted from consumption to production. By capturing events from multiple perspectives, we have the power to challenge official narratives, speak truth to power and expose tyranny. Coupled with social media, the moving image can affect political, social and cultural change; smartphones are able to help topple governments, transmit ideas and defend civil rights. Yet the moving image is also easily manipulated, making it an important arena in the battle for reality.
description_for_label: Smartphones democratised the moving image. With the power to record at our fingertips, we’re able to share information, bear witness and incite action. Our relationship to the moving image has shifted from consumption to production. By capturing events from multiple perspectives, we have the power to challenge official narratives, speak truth to power and expose tyranny. Coupled with social media, the moving image can affect political, social and cultural change; smartphones are able to help topple governments, transmit ideas and defend civil rights. Yet the moving image is also easily manipulated, making it an important arena in the battle for reality.

results.title: Humphrey B Bear
results.credit_line:
Plush toy (1976) and Hand puppet (1977), Classic Toys Pty Ltd. ACMI Collection. Donated by Daniel Clem, 2022

The Adventures of Humphrey Bear (1974), Gordon A. Rule, published by Rigby Ltd

Vinyl LP (1972), Jigsaw puzzle (1983), Mug & bowl (c.1983), Puzzle clock (1983), Bath book (1989), Southern Television Corp. Pty Ltd

Black and white publicity stills (1980s, ACMI Collection), Plaster moulding set (1991), Humphrey in the Snow VHS (1994, ACMI Collection, Banksia Productions
results.brief_description: The fun-loving Humphrey B Bear first bounded onto Australian TV in 1965 and has been bringing joy to children and adults ever since. Humphrey was the star of the Here’s Humphrey show, one of the world’s longest-running kids’ TV shows with around 3,000 episodes. Humphrey’s popularity is evident in all this merchandise and memorabilia. From plush toys and vinyl records to bath books and plaster sets, Humphrey has inspired children across decades to play, learn and create at home.

constellations_primary.name: Bear with me...
constellations_primary.description: From lovable anthropomorphic bears to hyperreal grizzlies, explore connections between cartoon and CGI bears across screen culture.

results.description: The fun-loving Humphrey B Bear first bounded onto Australian TV in 1965 and has been bringing joy to children and adults ever since. Humphrey was the star of the Here’s Humphrey show, one of the world’s longest-running kids’ TV shows with around 3,000 episodes. Humphrey’s popularity is evident in all this merchandise and memorabilia, which shows how Humphrey has inspired children across decades to play, learn and create at home.

results.title: House of Wax lobby cards
results.brief_description: Reproduction movie lobby card set for the promotio of the film ‘House of Wax’ a Warner Brothers production c1953. The set contains a series of eight colour pinted cards with illustrated scenes from the movie and graphic text noting ‘Natural Vision, Color by Warner Color, 3 Dimension, House of Wax.
results.description: Reproduction movie lobby card set for the promotio of the film ‘House of Wax’ a Warner Brothers production c1953. The set contains a series of eight colour pinted cards with illustrated scenes from the movie and graphic text noting ‘Natural Vision, Color by Warner Color, 3 Dimension, House of Wax.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-08. Immersive Innovations → MI-08-C01

results.title: House of Wax
results.brief_description: House of Wax was the first colour 3D feature film that incorporated stereo sround. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening the drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio.

constellations_primary.name: Movies on wax
constellations_primary.description: Waxing lyrical about the supernatural and early 21st-century teen stars.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

results.description: In the original trailer for House of Wax (1953), Warner Brothers heralded the third dimension as “the new wonder of the entertainment world”. Though that wonder had been discovered a year earlier in Bwana Devil (1952), Warner Brothers explored immersion further by releasing a colour 3D feature that incorporated stereo sound for the first time. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening tension and drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio. Both of these innovations are standard in filmmaking today.
description_for_label: In the original trailer for House of Wax (1953), Warner Brothers heralded the third dimension as “the new wonder of the entertainment world”. Though that wonder had been discovered a year earlier in Bwana Devil (1952), Warner Brothers explored immersion further by releasing a colour 3D feature that incorporated stereo sound for the first time. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening tension and drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio. Both of these innovations are standard in filmmaking today.

results.title: Hollow Knight
results.brief_description: Hollow Knight is an award-winning platforming game developed by Australian indie studio Team Cherry.

constellations_primary.name: Silent adventures (Hollow Knight - Education)
constellations_primary.description: Videogames, film and TV usually rely on the spoken word to communicate character and story. It wasn’t always this way. Although we may think of ‘silent films’ as in the past, there are contemporary videogames and films that shy away from using the spoken word.

results.description:
Hollow Knight is an award-winning platforming game developed by Australian indie studio Team Cherry.

Players explore vast underground catacombs of the ruined Hallownest kingdom. Much of the map is locked off to the player in the beginning but becomes accessible after the player finds key objects or gains new or enhanced skills.

Initially created through a successful Kickstarter campaign, Hollow Knight has playful animation, slick game mechanics and a unique gothic aesthetic that has seen it sell over a million copies worldwide.
description_for_label:
Hollow Knight is an award-winning platforming game developed by Australian indie studio Team Cherry.

Players explore vast underground catacombs of the ruined Hallownest kingdom. Much of the map is locked off to the player in the beginning but becomes accessible after the player finds key objects or gains new or enhanced skills.

Initially created through a successful Kickstarter campaign, Hollow Knight has playful animation, slick game mechanics and a unique gothic aesthetic that has seen it sell over a million copies worldwide.
